Package myTest

Class TestListIteratorSuite

java.lang.Object
myTest.TestListIteratorSuite
public class TestListIteratorSuite extends Object
Summary: The test suite TestListSuite collects test cases on methods of the ListAdapter.ListIterator class. This collection of test cases covers every method of the ListAdapter.ListIterator class and test their intended behaviour and edge-cases. The ListAdapter test cases are collected in a dedicated test suite.
Test Suite Design: The test suite contains test cases designed to test the intended behaviour of the ListAdapter.ListIterator class' methods and their edge-cases. In order to do so the test suite uses two instances of ListAdapter: an empty list and a generic list populated by an immutable collection of pokemon (referred to as pokedex).
Pre-Condition: none
Post-Condition: none
Test Cases:
  • testEmptyListIterator()
  • testIteratorFromIndex()
  • testAdd()
  • testHasNext()
  • testHasPrevious()
  • testNextPrevious()
  • testNext()
  • testPrevious()
  • testPreviousIndex()
  • testNextIndex()
  • testRemove()
  • testSet()

    • Test suite execution records:
    • JVM from JME CLDC 1.1
    • JUnit 4.13
    • Hamcrest 1.3

    Execution Variables:
    • String[] pokedex = {"Bulbasaur", "Ivysaur", "Venusaur", "Charmander", "Charmeleon", "Charizard", "Squirtle", "Wartortle", "Blastoise"};: An immutable array of pokemon from which the list istance of ListAdapter is populated.
    • HList list: an instance of ListAdapter populated by every pokemon in the pokedex.
    • HList emptylist: an empty instance of ListAdapter.
    Author:
    Zuech Riccardo
    See Also:

    • ListAdapter

    • Method Details

      • beforeClassMethod

        public static void beforeClassMethod()
        BeforeClass JUnit static method. Announces the the test begin and starts its timer.

      • setUp

        public void setUp()
        Before JUnit Method. It initialises the instances of ListAdapter used in this test suite.

      • afterClassMethod

        public static void afterClassMethod()
        AfterClass JUnit static method. Announces the the test end and stops its timer. Prints milliseconds elapsed from the beginning.

      • testEmptyListIterator

        public void testEmptyListIterator()
        Summary: test case for the listIterator() method of on an empty instance of the ListAdapter class
        Test Case Design: test the list iterator on an empty list

        Test Description: creates an iterator on the empty list and test the next and previous elements and their indexes.
        Pre-Condition: the list is empty
        Post-Condition: the list is still empty

        Expected Results: an iterator on an empty list has no previous or next element, therefore previousIndex() returns -1 and next() returns 0 as the iterator is always at the beginning of the list

      • testIteratorFromIndex

        public void testIteratorFromIndex()
        Summary: test case for the listIterator(int index) method of the ListAdapter class
        Test Case Design: test list iterators starting from every valid index of a pokedex list.

        Test Description: test the method when index is out of bounds. Then test that the iterator is placed before the provided index (for every valid index), so a subsequent call so next() returns the element in the list at the provided index, while previous() returns the element at index - 1.
        Pre-Condition: the pokedex list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex.
        Post-Condition: the pokedex list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex.

        Expected Results: calling the method with an index out of bounds throws IndexOutOfBoundsException. An iterator just created from the index i, is placed before i, so that a subsequent call to next() returns the element at the position i in the list, while a call to previous() returns the element at the position i - 1

      • testAdd

        public void testAdd()
        Summary: test case for the add(Object o) method of the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test the add(Object o) method on a pokedex list using an iterator starting from the middle of the list

        Test Description: create the list iterator starting from a valid position and test the insertion of the provided object before the implicit cursor, so that a subsequent call to next() would be unaffected but a subsequent call to previous() returns the added object.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex plus a new one outside the pokedex in the middle of the list

        Expected Results: the object has been added to the list (making it grow) and it's returned by a subsequent call to previous(), while a subsequent call to next() returns is unaffected. Implicitly the cursor has been moved by one on the right (as an element has been added before it) and therefore a subsequent call to nextIndex() returns its previous value + 1.

      • testHasNext

        public void testHasNext()
        Summary: test case for the hasNext() method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test the hasNext() method on a pokedex list

        Test Description: test the hasNext() method of an iterator starting from the beginning of the pokemon list by repeatedly calling next() while hasNext() returns true and then test calling next(). Test the value of nextIndex() when hasNext() is false.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: while hasNext() returns true, next() doesn't throw NoSuchElementException, but when hasNext() returns false a call to next() throws NoSuchElementException (as the iterator's cursor is at the end of the list). When hasNext() is false the iterator is at the end of the list so nextIndex() returns the size of the list.

      • testHasPrevious

        public void testHasPrevious()
        Summary: test case for the hasPrevious() method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test the hasNext() method on a pokedex list

        Test Description: test the hasNext() method of an iterator starting from the end of the pokemon list by repeatedly calling previous() while hasPrevious() returns true and then test calling previous(). Test the value previousIndex() when hasPrevious() is false.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: while hasPrevious() returns true, previous() doesn't throw NoSuchElementException, but when hasPrevious() returns false a call to previous() throws NoSuchElementException (as the iterator's cursor is at the beginning of the list). When hasPrevious() is false the iterator is at the beginning of the list so previousIndex() returns -1.

      • testNextPrevious

        public void testNextPrevious()
        Summary: test case for the interaction between the next() and previous() methods of the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: call previous and next back and forth on iterators from notable positions of a pokedex list.

        Test Description: test previous and next back and forth on an iterator from the end of the pokedex list, then test next and previous back and forth on an iterator from the beginning of the pokedex list.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: When the iterator is at the end of the list, let p be the value returned by previous() and n the value returned by next() called in this order, p is equal to the value of a subsequent call to previous() and n is equal to the value of a subsequent() call to next(). When the iterator is at the beginning of the list, let n be the value returned by next() and p the value returned by previous() called in this order, n is equal to the value of the subsequent call to next() and p is equal to the value of the subsequent call to previous().

      • testNext

        public void testNext()
        Summary: test case for the next() method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test next() on an iterator from the beginning of a pokedex list

        Test Description: Create a list iterator at the beginning of the pokedex list and test next() through the list. Test calling next() when the iterator is at the end of the list.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: calling next() through the list returns the correct sequence of elements in the list. Calling next() when the iterator is at the end of the list throws NoSuchElementException.

      • testNextIndex

        public void testNextIndex()
        Summary: test case for the nextIndex() method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test nextIndex() on an iterator from the beginning of a pokedex list

        Test Description: Create a list iterator at the beginning of the pokedex list and test nextIndex() through the list. Test calling nextIndex() when the iterator is at the end of the list.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: calling nextIndex() through the list returns a sequence of numbers from 0 to the size of the list (excluded). Calling nextIndex() when the iterator is at the end of the list returns the size of the list.

      • testPrevious

        public void testPrevious()
        Summary: test case for the previous() method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test previous() on an iterator from the end of a pokedex list

        Test Description: Create a list iterator at the end of the pokedex list and test previous() through the list. Test calling previous() when the iterator is at the beginning of the list.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: calling previous() through the list returns the inverted sequence of elements in the list. Calling previous() when the iterator is at the beginning of the list throws NoSuchElementException.

      • testPreviousIndex

        public void testPreviousIndex()
        Summary: test case for the previousIndex() method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test previousIndex() on an iterator from the end of a pokedex list

        Test Description: Create a list iterator at the end of the pokedex list and test previousIndex() through the list. Test calling previousIndex() when the iterator is at the ebginning of the list.
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: calling previousIndex() through the list returns a sequence of numbers from the size of the list (excluded) to -1. Calling previousIndex() when the iterator is at the beginning of the list returns -1.

      • testRemove

        public void testRemove()
        Summary: test case for the remove() method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test the remove() method on a pokedex list using an iterator starting from the middle of the list

        Test Description: create an iterator in the middle of the pokedex list and test remotion before and after calling previous() or next(). Then test calling the method after calling ListAdapterIterator.add(Object o) and at last test calling the method without calling previous() or next() since the last call to remove().
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with every pokemon in the pokedex

        Expected Results: Calling remove() removed the element returned by the last call to previous() or next(). If previous() or next() have not been called since the iterator creation or since the last call to remove(), or if ListAdapterIterator.add(Object o) has been called in the meanwhile, then remove() throws IllegalStateException

      • testSet

        public void testSet()
        Summary: test case for the set(Object o) method for the ListAdapterIterator class
        Test Case Design: test the set(Object o) method on a pokedex list using an iterator starting from the middle of the list

        Test Description: create an iterator in the middle of the pokedex list and test set(Object o) before and after calling previous() and next(). Then test calling the method when ListAdapterIterator.add(Object o) and ListAdapterIterator.remove() have been called between set(Object o) and the last call to previous()/next().
        Pre-Condition: the list is populated with every pokemon in the pokedex
        Post-Condition: the list is still populated with pokemon from the pokedex

        Expected Results: Calling set(Object o) set to o the element of the list returned by the last call to previous() and next(). If previous() or next() have not been called since the iterator creation or if ListAdapterIterator.add(Object o) or ListAdapterIterator.remove() have been called in the meanwhile and previous() or next() have not been called again, then set(Object o) throws IllegalStateException
